text:
Hope more companies give feedback and help you grow after the interview process when you don't get selected. I have given interviews for digital marketing role for around 5-10 companies and the experience has been more or less same and sometimes underwhelming.

A couple of companies that stood out were Wingman and Springworks. The person who interviewed me at Wingman sent across material on request and was responsive via LI and email helping me with most of my doubts. Sprigworks the entire process was seamless and helpful. We need more companies like this that leave a good taste even if you aren't getting selected. I personally wish both these companies reach great heights such was the experience.

elements.text:

text: How has been your experience so far <@U033Q4L80CT>

elements.text: How has been your experience so far

text:
• No one should make an employee feel threatened or insecure, it is a sign of a bad workplace/manager. Start looking out for other opps.
• Make a list of all the corrections/advice your manager gives you. Look at them often.
• Get the manager to give you a list of goals/targets for the month, or at least expectations ordered by priority (so that you know what you have to aim for).
• I recommend getting a Grammarly Premium account, if you write a lot at work. Or at least a free version. This will help you avoid typos, and smoothen out your writing - this goes a long way in improving your relationship with colleagues/manager in a remote setting.
• There are many parts in marketing (Content, running ads, marketing operations where you manage tools/reports and more). If one of those is not working for you, I suggest trying out some of the other ones, to see if you like any of them better. I got a chance to explore most of them in my first two jobs, it gave me a lot of clarity on my strengths as a marketer. Many orgs are in desperate need of a good marketing ops leader today. Worth exploring.
• Also, get a mentor who is honest and helpful, it really makes a big difference.

elements.text: No one should make an employee feel threatened or insecure, it is a sign of a bad workplace/manager. Start looking out for other opps.
Make a list of all the corrections/advice your manager gives you. Look at them often.
Get the manager to give you a list of goals/targets for the month, or at least expectations ordered by priority (so that you know what you have to aim for).

I recommend getting a Grammarly Premium account, if you write a lot at work. Or at least a free version. This will help you avoid typos, and smoothen out your writing - this goes a long way in improving your relationship with colleagues/manager in a remote setting.

There are many parts in marketing (Content, running ads, marketing operations where you manage tools/reports and more). If one of those is not working for you, I suggest trying out some of the other ones, to see if you like any of them better. I got a chance to explore most of them in my first two jobs, it gave me a lot of clarity on my strengths as a marketer. Many orgs are in desperate need of a good marketing ops leader today. Worth exploring.
Also, get a mentor who is honest and helpful, it really makes a big difference.

text:
Because there is a certain objection to paying the same for software built outside the US than built in the US.

That is going away slowly, but there are certain things you do to appease your audience, even after knowing it's an unfounded bias.

But we will live for the day when we will proudly put Bangalore, Chennai, Mumbai on our PR datelines.

text:
The first question you should ask is why do most SaaS companies sell to US?

High per capita income, means that, they have a higher incentive to automate jobs using software, which is more scalable, doesn't take leaves and is predictably priced at a fraction of what you would pay a human.

I think India will still remain at the low-end of the SaaS market in terms of total value.

Now a <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sxt4YCIsn2I|Dosa legend in NYC> will not say, "proudly made in San Francisco", he will proudly use his heritage as someone from Sri Lanka and someone used to learning South Indian recipes as a child, to sell his dosas.

This is a well studied phenomenon, also called as <https://www.wipo.int/geo_indications/en/|'Geographical Indication'> and the patent laws protect it.

It is why "french wine" is priced higher than Nashik wine, or scotch is priced higher than a whisky, even though they might be the same product essentially.

elements.text:

High per capita income, means that, they have a higher incentive to automate jobs using software, which is more scalable, doesn't take leaves and is predictably priced at a fraction of what you would pay a human.

I think India will still remain at the low-end of the SaaS market in terms of total value.

Now a
Dosa legend in NYC

will not say, "proudly made in San Francisco", he will proudly use his heritage as someone from Sri Lanka and someone used to learning South Indian recipes as a child, to sell his dosas.

This is a well studied phenomenon, also called as
'Geographical Indication'

and the patent laws protect it.

It is why "french wine" is priced higher than Nashik wine, or scotch is priced higher than a whisky, even though they might be the same product essentially.
